author: Zama Nteyi
title: McKenzie slammed for 'dodging' portfolio committee meetings
text: Gayton McKenzie, the Minister of Sports Arts and Culture, and his management, are accused of dodging Portfolio Committee meetings. McKenzie, acting director-general Dr Cynthia Khumalo, and other department officials, were supposed to attend an annual report meeting with the portfolio committee of sport, arts and culture, but they did not pitch. Mismanagement of funds on agenda One of the main items on the agenda was the mismanagement of funds in the department. This irregularity was revealed in the Auditor Generalâ€™s report. Chairperson of committee, Joe McGluwa, and committee members expressed a concern. They were not impressed, as this was the third time McKenzie and his team snubbed a committee meeting. McGluwa also indicated that the meeting was so important that it could not be postponed or cancelled. But without McKenzie and his accounting official, the meeting ended up being a futile and wasteful expenditure. A portfolio committee member, David Kgabo, said their role was to play an oversight role over the executive. This includes implementation of the legislation. â€œWeâ€™re here to discuss the annual report and the accounting authority is not here, not even the CFO. This must be noted as a concern. Weâ€™ve also noted that when the department is asked questions, they have a tendency to ignore the actual questions. Instead theyâ€™d respond to things that were never asked. They pick and choose which questions they want to answer,â€ said Kgabo. MacKenzie and team slammed for â€˜stinking attitudeâ€™ â€œAccording to the Auditor Generalâ€™s report, thereâ€™s mismanagement of funds, and someone must account for that. Who is going to account for the failures of the department when the minister himself is not here? We must take note of this stinking attitude from the department,â€ fumed Kgabo. He said that the department is entrusted with billions of rands. And people are not accounting, and they are doing as they please. â€œIâ€™m convinced that the minister is deliberately ignoring these meetings. Thereâ€™s generally no willingness to account. And itâ€™s about time we invite the Auditor General and Scopa to our next meeting. So that they can start to investigate.â€ McGluwa has since written to McKenzie and expressed his concerns. â€œThis is very serious and happening for the third time now. If it is not the non-appearance of officials, it is poorly prepared presentations that lack financial performance reporting,â€ McGluwa said in a letter. Formal complaint sent to minister â€œThis is against the spirit and principle of the three arms of the state. Nothing will ever be derived through undermining parliamentary oversight. At the Department of Sport, Arts, and Culture, we want responsive employees. Ones who are able to assist entities in their responsibility of service delivery to poor South Africans,â€ he said. A media inquiry was sent to Vusi Ndima, who attended the meeting. It was also sent to Zimasa Velaphi, the departmentâ€™s spokesperson. However, there was no response at the time of publishing.

author: Jamie Diep, KBBI - Homer
title: Passenger in Anchor Point plane crash dies as NTSB report shows buckled wing during descent - Alaska Public Media
text:
A screenshot of dashcam footage showing Kurt St. Jeanâ€™s Super Cub before it crashed along the Sterling Highway on Dec. 8, 2023. (From NTSB) The woman who was a passenger in a plane that crashed near Anchor Point earlier this month, killing the pilot, has died as federal investigators say one of the planeâ€™s wings was seen on video buckled during its descent.
The National Transportation Safety Board released a preliminary report Wednesday about the Dec. 8 crash that killed Kurt Stjean and seriously injured Kristen Fenske. Alaska State Troopers said Fenske died Wednesday morning.
Report_ANC24FA008_193500_12_27_2023 3_59_10 PM Download According to the report, the plane â€“ a Piper PA-18-150 â€“ was flying from King Salmon to Homer when it crashed at around 1:15 p.m. on Dec. 8. NTSB investigators retrieved video from a vehicleâ€™s dash camera that showed the plane spinning before the crash. While falling, the left wing appeared to be folded against the main body of the aircraft.
After the onsite investigation, the board brought the wreckage to Wasilla. There, a board investigator and structural engineer from the planeâ€™s manufacturer will examine the plane to determine the cause of the crash.
The plane wreckage near Anchor Point, seen during an on-site investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board. (From NTSB) Clint Johnson, the NTSBâ€™s Alaska chief, said the video indicates the left wing somehow failed before the crash.
â€œWe donâ€™t know what the initiating event was, but weâ€™re going to be centering it on the left wing at this point right now,â€ he said.
The investigation typically takes around a year to complete, Johnson said, but anything related to the aircraftâ€™s safety will be released immediately.
Johnson asked that any crash witnesses the board has not yet contacted to email witness@ntsb.gov.
Jamie Diep, KBBI - Homer

author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Reinforcing shot of cold air moving into South Florida
text:
Summary by Ground News First Warning meteorologist Vanessa Vinent says the cold will continue through Saturday morning. The cold air will be moving into South Florida Friday night and into the Treasure Coast and Palm Beaches on Saturday. The First Warning Meteorologist says the impact of the cold weather will be felt all day long. Share menu More
